thread.title: New Zealand police crack down on tourists driving slowly
thread.title_full: New Zealand police crack down on tourists driving slowly | Daily Mail Online

author: Sinead Maclaughlin For Daily Mail Australia
title: New Zealand police crack down on tourists driving slowly
text:
Police are targeting Asian drivers clogging up New Zealand roads across Chinese New Year.
Greymouth Sergeant Paul Watson says he has already dealt with a number of Asian drivers travelling slowly, causing locals to become frustrated and make risky road maneuvers.
'Around Chinese New Year we have a lot of Asian drivers on the roads. They seem to land in Christchurch and jump in a rental car to do the great West Coast route,' he told Stuff .
Police are targeting slow drivers clogging up New Zealand roads, as Chinese New Year brings a sharp increase of tourists
Greymouth Sergeant Paul Watson says he has already dealt with a number of Asian drivers travelling slowly, causing locals to become frustrated and make risky road maneuvers
Mr Watson urged locals to exercise patience and tolerance with drivers travelling slowly over the Chinese New Year holiday period, especially as they were unfamiliar with the New Zealand roads.
Fines of $150 and a loss of 20 demerit points could hit motorists who don't let traffic to pass by.
This also applies if they fail to move into slow vehicle bays, Stuff reports.
Up to 33,000 Chinese visitors are expected to visit New Zealand over the two weeks of Chinese New Year celebrations, according to Tourism New Zealand.
Around 450,000 Chinese tourists visited the country in the last year alone, overtaking visitors from the US and the UK, according to AA spokesman Simon Douglas.
'It's undoubtable we will see more Chinese drivers on the roads particularly around Chinese New Year,' he told Stuff.
Locals are urged to exercise patience and tolerance with drivers travelling slowly over the Chinese New Year period, especially as they were unfamiliar with the New Zealand roads
Up to 33,000 Chinese visitors are expected to visit New Zealand shores over the two weeks of Chinese New Year celebrations, according to Tourism New Zealand
